etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in The Contemporary Review. From French chantefable from chanter to sing + fable, as modernizing alteration of Old French cantefable cantefable

definitions: A medieval French ballad, consisting of parts of spoken prose alternating with parts of sung verse; this type of ballad as a literary genre.

notes.text: Often with reference to the 13th-cent. text Aucassin et Nicolette; see note at cantefable.

definitions: Any text, work, or performance consisting partly of prose and partly of (sung or recited) verse.
